The Project will support environmentally sustainable development 
in Fuzhou and benefit 1.85 million residents. New and expanded 
wastewater collection and treatment facilities, rehabilitated creeks 
and  improved  water  quality  and  flood  control  management  will 
improve  living  conditions  and  public  health  standards.  Indirectly,

quality  and  environmental  conditions,  increased  access  to  safe 
drinking  water,  and  reduced  incidence  of  water-borne  diseases.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Fuzhou  Environmental  Improvement  Project 
(the Project). 
 
2. 
The  Government  asked  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  help  improve  the 
environmental quality of its cities, which continue to expand as the economy grows rapidly. The 
Project is in Fuzhou, the capital of Fujian Province, one of the PRC’s high-growth provinces and 
most active proponents of environment protection. The Project is consistent with ADB’s Water 
Policy,  and  will  help  the  PRC  achieve  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  of  environmental 
sustainability  and  increased  access  to  safe  drinking  water  and  basic  sanitation.  This  report  is 
based on the findings of the loan Appraisal Mission and discussions with the central and local 
governments,  relevant  agencies,  and  community  organizations.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.   
 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Since the PRC initiated economic reforms in 1978, rapid urbanization has accompanied 
significant economic progress. The urban population has grown from about 190 million in 1980 
to more than 524 million in 2003, and now accounts for about 40% of the total population. The 
Government’s Agenda for Economic Reform and Social Development in the New Century aims 
to  accelerate  urbanization  and  the  development  of  large,  medium,  and  small  cities  as  well  as 
small towns. The urban population is expected to reach 700 million, half of the total population, 
in 2030.1 Increasing urban population, industrialization, and economic development are putting 
pressure  on  an  overloaded  urban  infrastructure,  and  contributing  to  widespread  pollution  and 
environmental  threats  in  the  PRC’s  cities.  The  rising  demand  for  basic  municipal  services  is 
outstripping  the  financial  and  physical  capacity  of  most  urban  centers.  The  environmental 
threats  facing  the  PRC’s  urban  areas  include  the  pollution  of  creeks,  lakes,  and  underground 
aquifers from untreated water. 
 
4. 
In  2003,  municipal  sources  generated  65%  of  the  country’s  estimated  46  billion  cubic 
meters  (m3)  of  wastewater,  while  industrial  sources  generated  35%  of  the  total.2  As  the 
development of municipal wastewater treatment is still in the early stages, only 40% is treated. 
The  rest  is  discharged  untreated  into  rivers  and  lakes.  Although  about  90%  of  industrial 
wastewater is treated, much of it is only pretreated to a low effluent standard before discharge 
into  a  municipal  sewer.  In  the  absence  of  a  centralized  municipal  wastewater  treatment  plant 
(WWTP),  a  mixture  of  raw  municipal  wastewater  and  partially  treated  industrial  wastewater  is 
discharged from the municipal sewer to the nearest body of water.  
 
5. 
Municipal  wastewater  is  a  major  contributor  to  pollution  of  the  PRC’s  rivers  and  lakes, 
with the water-deficient northern region of the country the most severely impacted. In regional 
and  administratively  higher-level  cities,  only  30%  of  the  rivers  meet  their  designated  water

6. 
Recognizing that adequate environmental protection and pollution controls are essential 
for sustainable economic growth, the Government has incorporated environmental protection as 
national  priority  into  its  development  strategy.  The  Government  has  enacted  environmental 
protection laws and implementing regulations that emphasize preventive measures, the polluter 
pays principle, and decentralized environmental management. In addition, the Government has 
undertaken numerous programs, including those for wastewater management.6 Industries were 
ordered to treat wastewater to acceptable standards by the end of 2000. Under successive 5-
year  plans,  municipalities  were  required  to  address  wastewater  collection,  treatment,  and 
disposal.  Pollution  control  plans  also  were  developed  and  partially  implemented  for  the  key 
water basins. The Tenth Five-Year Plan stipulates that regional and administratively higher-level 
cities  have  to  treat  45%  of  municipal  wastewater,  while  cities  discharging  more  than  500,000 
m3/day have to treat 60%. National guidelines further require that major cities, such as provincial 
capitals,  achieve  a  wastewater  treatment  rate  of  70%  by  2010.7  The  treatment  level  required 
depends on the water quality class of the receiving water. To achieve water quality Class I, II, or 
III, secondary wastewater treatment normally would be required. 
 
7. 
However,  the  Government  is  concerned  that  the  water  pollution  control  targets  of  the 
Tenth Five-Year Plan might not be achieved due to (i) inadequate investment, (ii) the failure to 
phase  out  outdated  technology  and  polluting  companies,  and  (iii)  weak  monitoring  and 
enforcement  in  some  localities.  To  address  this  concern,  the  Government  has  made  the 
prevention  of  urban  environmental  degradation  a  high  priority,  and  has  been  seeking  the 
cooperation of provincial and local governments to speed up the implementation of wastewater 
treatment  projects.  Financing  the  huge  infrastructure  needs  requires  appropriate  instruments 
and  incentives  for  channeling  a  larger  share  of  domestic  savings  into  the  sector,  and  for 
attracting private sector capital. To this end, the Government is (i) developing domestic capital 
markets,  (ii)  promoting  the  use  of  foreign  capital,  (iii)  introducing  price  reforms  and  user  fees, 
(iv)  creating  a  legal  and  policy  framework  to  attract  private  sector  participation  (PSP),  and  (v) 
strengthening  the  ability  of  local  governments  to  raise  funds  for  infrastructure  development. 
Fujian, a fast-developing province in the eastern region, has responded to this challenge. It has 
become one of the most active proponents of urban environment improvement in the country.

9. 
The  Fuzhou  Urban  Master  Plan  (FUMP:  1995–2010)  is  the  blueprint  for  the  physical, 
economic, and social development of Fuzhou. To meet the environmental objectives, the FUMP 
has  underscored  the  need  to  construct  municipal  wastewater  facilities  to  control  wastewater 
discharges. Fuzhou is served by two WWTPs: the Xiangban WWTP, with a capacity of 50,000 
m3/day;  and  the  ADB-funded  Yangli  WWTP  Phase  1,  with  a  capacity  of  200,000  m3/day.9  As 
these two WWTPs can treat only about half of the wastewater generated, additional treatment 
capacity  and  expanded  sewer  networks  are  needed  to  meet  the  growing  demand.  Under  the 
proposed Project, the Yangli Phase 2 Sewer Networks will expand the service coverage for the 
Yangli Phase 1 from 60% to 90% of the population, resulting in a more comprehensive sewer 
system under the FUMP. The Yangli WWTP Phase 2, which will increase capacity by 100,000 
m3/day,  will  be  constructed  using  municipal  funds.  To  rectify  a  similar  deficiency  in  the 
wastewater  system  on  Nantai  Island,  a  main  focus  of  future  urban  development,  the  Fuzhou 
municipal  government  (FMG)  will  construct  the  Lianban  Sewer  Network  to  connect  with  the 
proposed  Lianban  WWTP,  which  is  to  be  constructed  with  PSP.  With  an  initial  capacity  of 
150,000 m3/day, the proposed Lianban WWTP will complement the Jinshan WWTP, which was 
constructed recently using the build-operate-transfer (BOT) modality. FMG seeks to treat 65% 
of  wastewater  and  provide  80%  sewer  service  coverage  by  2009.  By  2010,  a  70%  treatment 
rate is envisaged. The plan’s water quality target is Class III for Min River and at least Class V 
for the other inland creeks. Under Fujian provincial government (FPG) and FMG policy, sources 
of financing for the construction of all new WWTPs are to be diversified. 
 
10. 
The  FUMP  also  seeks  to  clean  up  and  rehabilitate  the  inland  creek  system  on  Nantai 
Island, which will become a high-tech park, business center, residential area, and tourism spot. 
The  Lianban  Sewer  Network  will  provide  central  Nantai  Island  with  the  required  wastewater 
service system, and ensure that the rehabilitated creeks achieve their environmental protection 
target and water quality standards. The natural inland waterways on Nantai Island were formed 
when storm runoff scoured fluvial deposits, resulting in a maze of small drainage channels. This 
fragmented drainage system is ineffective. Storm water runoff causes widespread flooding, and 
the water in the creeks is polluted with untreated wastewater. The Lianban Sewer Network will 
be  constructed  in  coordination  with  the  rehabilitation  of  the  creeks  to  ensure  that  the 
environment of Nantai Island is improved. Interceptors will be constructed parallel to the creeks 
to convey wastewater to the WWTPs, and to ensure water quality will be maintained when the 
rehabilitation is completed.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

11.  Wastewater management in the PRC provides numerous opportunities to reduce water 
pollution, protect water resources, promote sustainable economic development, promote public-
private partnerships in urban infrastructure, and improve the living conditions and public health 
of  urban  residents,  including  the  poor.  The  Government  needs  assistance  to  achieve  the 
Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs)  for  environmental  sustainability  (MDG  7),  and  to  half 
the proportion of people without sustainable access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation 
by 2015 (MDG 10 and 11).10 
 
12. 
In the PRC’s centrally planned economy, the Government was the sole provider of urban 
services.  Wastewater  management  was  based on  septic tanks  and  designated  open  drainage 
ditches  with  no  treatment.  Tax  revenue  funded  services,  while  consumers  paid  minimal  or  no 
charges.  Over  the  past decade,  the  Government  has  shifted  fundamentally  towards  a  market-
based  approach,  enterprise  provision  in  the  delivery  of  infrastructure  services,  and  a  more 
integrated  approach  to  urban  management.  The  PRC  policies  incorporate  the  need  for 
complementary  reforms  to  support  investment,  particularly  from  the  private  sector,  in  urban 
infrastructure. Improvements in service delivery through investment in wastewater systems are 
increasingly  being  matched  by  financial,  governance,  and  enterprise  reform;  public  education; 
awareness; and social responsibility. Although much progress has been made, the Government 
believes the pace of change needs to be accelerated.11 Investment in wastewater management

centralized  WWTPs.  The  WWTPs,  which  will  employ  the  same  treatment  processes

head  works  of  the  WWTP.  The  technical  features  of  the  WWTPs  will  address  the  risk  from

51. 
PRC  environmental  policy  takes  a  cost-effective  approach  to  pollution  control  and 
wastewater  management  through  specific  treatment  rate  targets  and  required  water  quality 
standards for water bodies. After initially targeting large point-source polluters, the policy is now 
focused on major population centers. Major cities, including Fuzhou, should have a wastewater 
treatment rate of 70% by 2010. The Min River Basin Plan28 sets the water quality requirement 
for the Fuzhou stretch of the Min River as Class III. As part of a national program to expedite 
wastewater  management  plans,  a  target  city  treatment  rate  of  70%  seems  reasonable.  The 
Class III requirement for the Min River, the source of the city’s water supply, is in line with the 
requirements for potable water sources established and enforced by SEPA. 
 
52. 
For Fuzhou, FMG has adapted its planning process to meet the enormous challenges of 
rapid  economic  growth  and  urbanization.  The  FUMP29  is  a  comprehensive  document  that 
provides  a  strategic  vision  of  sustainable  economic  development  in  Fuzhou.  The  FUMP  has 
identified a series of short-term actions to halt the deterioration of water quality, and long-term 
actions  to  address  the  environmental  problems  and  to  protect  water  resources,  including  the 
Min  River.  For  wastewater  and  water  resources  protection,  the  FUMP  designates  water 
resources protection zones for more stringent environmental controls, and targets point-source 
polluters first as the most cost-effective approach to improving ambient water quality. Evidence 
suggests  that  many  of  the  priority  actions  have  been  taken.  Plans  for  sewer  networks  and 
WWTPs  are  detailed  and  updated  in  the  Fuzhou  Wastewater  Master  Plan.30  The  investment 
program prioritized drainage areas, making use of existing sewer networks first. The program is 
integrated  well,  and  coordinated  with,  improvements  in  existing  and  developing  urban  areas. 
Without  the  project  systems,  two  new  WWTPs  (funded  by  third  parties)  cannot  become 
operational  and  the  goal  of  treating  70%  of  wastewater  will  not  be  met.  The  proposed  inland 
creek rehabilitation component is coordinated well. The 13 creeks identified are part of drainage 
areas  that  already  have  collection  and  treatment  systems,  or  will  have  new  systems  provided 
under the Project. 
 
53. 
The sewer networks systems and the inland creek rehabilitation program were designed 
based on capital, technical, and implementation considerations that can provide the most cost-
effective  solution.  The  design  of  the  systems  (i)  limits  resettlement,  where  possible;  (ii) 
minimizes  pumping  to  reduce  operations  costs;  and  (iii)  optimizes  sewer  layouts  to  achieve 
minimum  disruption  and  least  cost  in  laying  sewers,  while  allowing  maximum  flexibility  for 
expansion. Estimates of the unit cost of sewer networks and treatment illustrate economies of 
scale.  Although  unit  rates  for  individual  systems  vary  according  to  procurement  method,  size, 
and technical considerations, the average economic cost of the system will decline gradually as 
the wastewater treatment rate in the city increases (Appendix 13).

The National Policy and Regulatory Framework 

 
 
A. 
 
1. 
Before  the  1990s,  the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  was  the 
sole provider of urban services. Wastewater management practice was based on septic tanks, 
designated  open  drainage  ditches,  and  no  treatment.  Services  were  funded  through  tax 
revenue, with consumers paying minimal or no charges. In view of the rapid economic growth 
and  urban  expansion,  the  Government  recognized  the  need  to  implement  environmental 
protection  measures  alongside  economic  growth  policies  to  meet  its  vision  of  clean,  modern, 
and environmentally sustainable cities that are competitive in the global market. As a result, the 
Government  shifted  fundamentally  towards  a  market-based  approach,  enterprise  provision  in 
the delivery of infrastructure services, and an integrated approach to urban management. 
 
2. 
 The  Water  Pollution  and  Prevention  Law  (1996)  authorizes  setting  standards  for 
ambient  surface  water  quality,1  and  uses  these  standards  to  set  targets  for  individual 
watercourses. The State Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA) defines the technical 
standards  at  a  national  level,  including  standards  that  apply  to  sections  of  creeks  or  other 
watercourses  of  strategic  significance.  For  other  creeks  and  watercourses,  the  relevant 
environmental protection department at the municipal or provincial level sets the targeted water 
quality class. 
 
3. 
The PRC’s successive 5-year plans have set targets and requirements for achieving the 
designated water quality classes. Provincial and municipal governments are called upon to draft 
specific plans to address wastewater collection, treatment, and disposal. Industries are provided 
with  regulations  on  effluent  standards  before  discharge  to  a  municipal  sewer.  Industries  are 
required  to  provide  adequate  wastewater  treatment  to  meet  regulatory  pollution  limits.  For 
municipal  wastewater,  the  level  of  treatment  is  determined  by  the  water  quality  class  of  the 
receiving  water  and  specific  target  treatment  rates.  The  targets  in  the  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan 
(TFYP) were a wastewater treatment rate of 45% for regional and higher level cities, and 60% 
for cities discharging more than 500,000 m3/day by 2005. The Ministry of Construction (MCon) 
set  a  more  stringent  target  of  a  70%  treatment  rate  for  larger  cities  (e.g.,  major  cities  and 
provincial capitals) by 2010.2 
 
4. 
Several  other  policies,  regulations,  and  plans  support  the  framework  for  water  quality 
management. Building regulations from the MCon (dating to the 1980s) require the construction 
of septic tanks for all new residential and other non-industrial developments. New developments 
are  excused  from  this  requirement  if  the  discharge  is  to  a  municipal  sewer  connected  to  a 
wastewater  treatment  plant  (WWTP).  The  TFYP  also  requires  substantial  progress  in

Progress  in  environmental  management  was  made  during  the  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan 
6. 
(1995–2000).  By  1999,  the  discharge  volume  of  major  pollutants,  including  chemical  oxygen 
demand  and  petroleum-related  products,  had  declined  by  15–25%  from  1995  levels.  Much  of 
the  progress  was  made  in  industrial  pollution  in  line  with  Government  policy  to  target  major 
point-source polluters first. Many polluting industries were closed down, while others invested in 
on-site wastewater treatment. ADB supported some of those initiatives. By 2002, the PRC had 
an estimated 537 municipal WWTPs. 
 
 In  2003,  46  billion  m3  of  wastewater  was  generated.  Growth  in  domestic3  wastewater 
7. 
generation (about 65% of the total) is outpacing the reductions in industrial wastewater (about 
35% of the total). Since about 40% of the domestic wastewater generated is treated, an annual 
volume  of  around  18  billion  m3  of  wastewater  is  left  untreated.  In  the  absence  of  a  municipal 
WWTP,  a  mixture  of  raw  domestic  wastewater  and  partially  treated  industrial  wastewater  is 
discharged  from  the  municipal  sewer  into  the  nearest  body  of  water.  Designated  open 
wastewater ditches are still common in many cities. Municipal wastewater is a major contributor 
to  the  pollution  of  rivers  and  lakes,  with  the  most  severe  pollution  impacts  in  the  water-short 
northern region of the country. 
 
8. 
In regional and higher level cities, only 30% of rivers meet their designated water quality 
standards—half the objective of 60% in the TFYP. In seven major river basins,4 52% of rivers do 
not meet the Class III standard required for sources of potable water. More than half the rivers 
in urban areas are the lowest quality standard (Class V) or below—16% are Class V standard, 
while 36% are worse than that. Eutrophication is occurring in three quarters of major fresh water 
lakes.  Surface  water  sources  serving  municipal  water  supply  systems  are  polluted  to 
unacceptable water quality standards. The water quality in groundwater aquifers is deteriorating. 
Much more investment in collection systems and municipal WWTPs is needed. WWTPs are the 
key  to  water  pollution  control,  since  the  industrial  treatment  plants  typically  only  pretreat 
wastewater to a low effluent standard before discharge into a municipal sewer. Social surveys 
suggest  that  the  urban  population  is  becoming  increasingly  concerned  about  the  impact  of 
wastewater  pollution.  Although  wastewater  companies  have  been  established  in  many  cities, 
few are financially or managerially autonomous, and tariff increases have been slow.

The  Fuzhou  Urban  Master  Plan  (FUMP:  1995–2010)  is  the  blueprint  for  the  physical,

and  emphasized  that  municipal  wastewater  facilities  need  to  be  constructed  to  control 
wastewater discharges. To address the shortfall in wastewater facilities in the developed areas 
of  Fuzhou,  and  to  properly  prepare  for  the  development  of  Nantai  Island,  the  FUMP  includes 
five  WWTPs  and  associated  sewer  networks  in  Fuzhou,  and  a  comprehensive  inland  creek 
rehabilitation  program  to  improve  the  environment  of  Nantai  Island.  In  addition,  the  Fuzhou 
municipal  government  (FMG)  adopted  a  target  of  Class  III  for  the  Fuzhou  stretch  of  the  Min 
River in the Fuzhou Urban Master Plan. To meet the water quality target for the Min River and 
comply  with  Government  regulations  to  treat  70%  of  municipal  wastewater  by  2010,  FMG  is 
implementing the Fuzhou Wastewater Master Plan. That plan divides the city into five drainage 
areas,  and  targets  the  dense  urban  areas  for  priority  investment  in  a  cost-effective  approach. 
The plan’s water quality target is Class III for Min River and Class V or better for inland creeks. 
 
10.  Wastewater collected in the sewer networks will be treated in the relevant WWTPs, and 
then discharged to the adjacent creeks. The Min River is the ultimate receiving water body of all 
the inland creeks. With its large runoff flow and substantial dilution and self-purifying capacity, 
Min River’s water quality in its trunk is better than Class III. However, a significant pollution belt 
has  developed  near  shore  in  Min  River’s  Fuzhou  urban  section  due  to  large  untreated 
wastewater  discharges.  This  poses  a  threat  to  water  quality  and  the  ecological  system  of  the 
Min River. One of the objectives for WWTP construction and creek rehabilitation is to eliminate 
the pollution belt near shore, and to minimize its adverse impacts. To achieve the objectives of 
the  Project,  FMG  will  ensure  that  the  construction  of  the  Lianban  WWTP  and  Yangli  WWTP 
Phase  2  are  coordinated  with  project  implementation.  Though  the  Lianban  WWTP  and  Yangli

project  preparation  for  the  two  WWTPs  has  been  closely  coordinate  with  preparation  for  the

Phase  1.  The  current  coverage  area  is  insufficient,  limiting  improvement  in  water  quality  and 
environmental protection. With the additional coverage from the Phase 2 sewer system, 90% of 
the  urban  area  of  Fuzhou  will  be  served.  The  more  comprehensive  sewer  system  will

1. 
Lack  of  facilities  and  poor  hygiene  contribute  to  the  health  problems  of  the  poor. 
Improved sanitation and knowledge of hygiene contribute to better livelihoods, especially for the 
poor and vulnerable groups. Despite these clear benefits, hygiene promotion and education is 
accorded a low priority compared with other livelihood needs. The key objective of the Fuzhou 
Environmental Improvement Project (the Project) is to improve living conditions and the public 
health of 1.85 million people, of which 7% are categorized as urban poor in Fuzhou City. One of 
the  project  components  is  the  rehabilitation  of  the  Nantai  Island  inland  creek  system.  The 
system’s  40  or  more  inland  creeks  play  major  roles  as  drainage  systems  for  sewerage  and 
rainstorms.  All  of  them  discharge  into  the  Min  River.  As  Nantai  Island  lacks  a  centralized 
wastewater treatment facility, all domestic and industrial wastewater is discharged directly into 
the nearest creek. Most households along the creeks dump their solid waste into creeks, which 
creates more pollution. This pollution has caused the deterioration of the water quality in the Min 
River.  Water  quality  in  these  creeks  is  worse  than  the  lowest  national  standard  (Class  V). 
Rehabilitating  the  system  of  creeks  and  upgrading  the  environment  are  prerequisites  for  the 
environmentally  sustainable  development  of  the  island.  To  maximize  the  project  benefits, 
particularly to the urban poor, a hygiene educational program is needed. This pilot program will 
cover 50 villages on Nantai Island, benefiting 2,000 households.

creation and promotion of sustainable economic development in areas where the poor are particularly likely to gain, 
such as tourism development. Due to their higher vulnerability to pollution, the poor will benefit from improvement in 
living conditions and environmental quality. The Project will support the achievement of the Millennium Development 
Goal (MDG) for environmental sustainability (MDG Goal 7), and to half the proportion of people without sustainable 
access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation by 2015 (MDG targets 10 and 11). 
 
B. 
 
The Project will benefit an urban population of 1.85 million through the provision clean water and improved sanitation. 
Within the beneficiary population, about 109,700 persons (or 7.7%) are classified as poor, according to the weighted 
average local urban poverty line of CNY2,640 per year. The Project will provide 6,648 person-years of employment 
opportunities  during  construction,  of  which  the  poor  will  fill  an  estimated  2,600  person-years.  The  Project  has 
prioritized  40%  of  these  jobs  for  the  poor.  Project  operations  will  create  40  full-time  permanent  jobs  for  the  poor. 
Project-related  services,  such  as  procurement  of  construction  materials  and  equipment,  will  provide  an  additional 
3,420  person-years  of  employment.  Those  temporarily  employed  in  construction  operations  will  benefit  from 
additional training and experience that will provide them with opportunities in planned infrastructure construction. The 
Project will improve sewage services and sanitary conditions, contribute to a reduction in morbidity and mortality rates 
of waterborne diseases, and savings in associated medical costs and loss of working days. The common waterborne 
diseases  in  Fuzhou  include  hepatitis  and  dysentery.  Research  by  the  Central  South  Hospital  of  Wuhan  University 
concluded  that  each  case  of  hepatitis  or  dysentery  results  in  CNY480  of  direct  medical  costs,  and  30  days  of  lost 
working  time.  The  loss  of  agricultural  production  can  be  reduced  through  the  improved  quality  of  irrigation  water. 
Improving  water quality from Class V to Class III  will support the development of the  water-based tourism industry, 
providing another source of employment in the local communities. The Project will support an increase in visitors by 
260,000 per year and a revenue increase of CNY350 million per year from tourism. Women and the poor will benefit 
from the tourism, as they make up a large proportion of tourism operators and vendors. Less pollution and improved 
water  quality  of  the  receiving  water  bodies  will  lower  the  cost  of  treatment  for  Fuzhou’s  existing  and  future  water 
supply  plants,  which  will  be  passed  on  to  the  consumers.  Socioeconomic  losses  from  severe  water  logging  and 
flooding  can  be  prevented.  Flooding  causes  about  CNY146.22  million  of  industrial  and/or  commercial,  agricultural, 
and private property losses once every 5 years. The Project will help avoid these losses. The poor, women, children, 
and  elderly  are  vulnerable  to  flooding  and  water  logging.  The  improved  environment  will  contribute  to  a  better 
atmosphere for investment. However, increases in the fees for water and wastewater treatment might harm the poor.

Summary  

 
A. 
 
The  economic  analysis  was  undertaken  using  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
1. 
guidelines.1  The  analysis  draws  from  an  ADB  paper,  Economic  Issues  in  the  Design  and 
Analysis  of  a  Wastewater  Treatment  Project    which  looks  at  the  specific  characteristics  of 
wastewater  projects,  and  sets  out  the  importance  of  considering  any  proposed  wastewater 
project as “one small part in a greater system to manage ambient water quality.” It recommends 
an  approach  to  economic  analysis  that  is  more  appropriate  for  most  wastewater  management 
projects than standard benefit-cost analysis.2 The basic concept is that if standards and targets 
for ambient  quality water appear well founded, reasonable, and partly driven by social choice, 
as  long  as  the  mechanisms  for  monitoring  and  enforcement  are  in  place,  then  the  economic 
approach to meeting those targets is one of least cost. 
 
2. 
This  analysis  considers  the  proposed  Fuzhou  Environmental  Improvement  Project  (the 
Project)  as  an  integrated  part  of  an  ongoing  city,  municipal,  and  basin-wide  environmental 
program, rather than as a stand-alone investment. As such, environmental goals are achieved 
jointly  with  other  policies  and  investments.  The  economic  analysis  provides  an  in-depth 
economic  rationale  based  on  policy,  sector,  and  local  area  analysis.  Further,  it  examines  the 
least  cost  approach  to  achieving  environmental  objectives.  This  analysis  purports  that  the 
established  plans  are  a  reasonable  approach  to  managing  environmental  protection  and 
ambient water quality, and to planning for sustainable urban development. The analysis shows 
that the Project is a critical component of those established plans, and represents a least cost 
approach  to  achieving  incremental  improvements  in  environmental  quality.  Although  limited  in 
scope,  the  Project  showed  reasonable  support  through  public  participation  in  the  planning 
process, and through consultations under the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA). 
 
B. 
 
3. 
The environmental policy of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) takes a cost-effective 
approach  to  pollution  control  and  wastewater  management  through  specific  treatment  rate 
targets and required water quality standards for water bodies. Major point-source polluters were 
targeted  first  followed  by  major  centers  of  population,  which  is  the  current  focus.  Guidelines 
from  the  Ministry  of  Construction  set  more  stringent  targets  than  the  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan 
(TFYP), requiring major cities, including Fuzhou, to treat 70% of wastewater by 2010. The Min 
River  Basin  Plan  establishes  the  water  quality  requirement  for  the  Fuzhou  stretch  of  the  Min 
River as Class III. As part of a national program to expedite wastewater management plans, a 
target city treatment rate of 70% seems reasonable. The Class III requirement for the Min River, 
the source of the city’s water supply, is in line with PRC requirements for potable water sources.

the enormous challenges presented by rapid urbanization and economic growth. Over the past 
decade,  population  has  doubled  and  gross  domestic  product  has  increased  sevenfold.  Urban 
planning and economic development in the city is based  on the TFYP (2000–2005), while the

facilitate further expansion, and attract private sector investment.
